elements.title: Guarantee-First Visual Anchor
elements.problem: Mahesh asks about financial protection three separate times across a 13-minute call (payment guarantee at 02:17 and 10:45, deposit at 09:34, property damage at 12:04). L2 identifies a 'Risk-Absorption-First Information Hierarchy' where guarantees must be the first thing the host sees. But information hierarchy alone does not solve the problem -- the visual treatment of guarantee information must signal permanence, authority, and unconditional protection at a glance. If guarantee badges look like secondary metadata (small type, muted color, standard weight), the host's eye will skip them even if they are positioned correctly. Cold Start Theory shows the hard side 'will try competitive products to compare' -- meaning the guarantee must visually outcompete anything Furnished Finder shows. The visual challenge is: how do you make a text-based guarantee feel as solid and immovable as the financial promise it represents, using the purple production palette to convey institutional authority without coldness?
elements.solution: Create a dedicated 'Protection Status' visual component that uses the deepest primary purple (#31135D) as a solid background fill with white text, positioned at the top of every commitment-adjacent screen (proposal card, pricing confirmation, lease dashboard). The component uses Inter at --font-weight-bold (700) and --text-md (16px) for the headline ('Payment Guaranteed: $2,600/mo') and --text-sm (12px) / --font-weight-medium (500) for the secondary line ('Property Protected: $1M Coverage Active'). The dark-purple fill with white text creates the highest-contrast, most visually anchoring element on the screen -- the host's eye is drawn to it before any lighter-background content below. A subtle left-border accent in --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) at 3px width differentiates this from standard cards while reinforcing the brand. The component is non-collapsible and non-dismissible. On the active lease dashboard, it becomes a persistent header bar with a live status indicator (a small 8px circle in --accent-purple) confirming real-time coverage. The visual principle: guarantees are rendered in the visual language of permanence (darkest background, highest weight, top position), not in the visual language of notification (light background, standard weight, dismissible).

evidence.quote: Even if you are not able to find this ghost roommate setup, I'm still getting paid whatever first month.
evidence.insight: Mahesh's most important question is about payment certainty. The visual treatment must match this priority: the guarantee is not supplementary information -- it is the foundational visual element that anchors the entire screen hierarchy.

evidence.quote: How does the deposit get sorted out? Is that something that I would work with you or would that with the...
evidence.insight: The host needs to see property protection and counterparty clarity at a glance. The visual component must convey both the coverage amount and the counterparty (Split Lease) without requiring the host to read body text.

evidence.quote: Users on the hard side have complex workflows, expect status benefits as well as financial outcomes, and will try competitive products to compare.
evidence.insight: The hard side comparison-shops visually as well as substantively. If the guarantee looks like a tooltip or badge, it loses to a competitor that makes its value proposition visually dominant. The guarantee must be the most visually prominent element on the screen.

spacing: --spacing-2xl (24px) bottom margin to separate from content below

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AAA. White (#FFFFFF) on primary-purple (#31135D) yields a contrast ratio of approximately 13.5:1, exceeding AAA large-text (4.5:1) and AAA normal-text (7:1) requirements. The accent-purple indicator dot on white background yields approximately 3.2:1, acceptable for decorative/non-text elements.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye sees the dark-purple guarantee bar first (highest contrast block on the page), then drops to the guest identity section below it (medium contrast), then to logistics and details (lowest contrast). The guarantee bar is never below the fold and never visually subordinate to any other element on the screen.
elements.brand_alignment: Maps directly to taste model principle 'Trustworthy, not corporate' -- the dark fill signals institutional authority while the rounded corners (--rounded-lg, 8px) and the Inter typeface keep it approachable. The 'Confident, not flashy' principle is served by the solid fill rather than a gradient, and by the absence of icons or decorative elements -- the guarantee speaks through data, not embellishment.

elements.title: Agent-to-Platform Trust Transfer Visual Bridge
elements.problem: L0 identifies that all trust in Mahesh's journey is concentrated in Bryant, the human agent, not in the platform. L2 defines an 'Agent-to-Platform Trust Transfer Architecture' with a personalized handoff screen. The visual challenge is distinct from the information challenge: even with the right content, the handoff screen must visually feel like a continuation of a warm human conversation, not like a generic SaaS onboarding. Mahesh's only reference is Furnished Finder (07:29: 'I've never heard of this company... you're doing experience similar to Furnished Finder'). If the first platform screen looks like every other proptech dashboard -- gray backgrounds, standard cards, no personalization -- the visual language signals 'generic tool,' not 'the place Bryant told you about.' Cold Start Theory documents how Slack's Stewart Butterfield 'personally handled 10,000 tweets per month' -- but Butterfield's personality eventually had to become Slack's visual personality. The same transition must happen for Bryant-to-SplitLease.
elements.solution: Design the first-visit handoff screen with a distinctive visual treatment that separates it from every subsequent visit. Use the warm off-white background (--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) -- slightly warmer than the standard --bg-light (#f9fafb) -- to create a subtle sense of specialness. The agent's note section uses a left-aligned vertical accent bar in --secondary-purple (3px wide) with the agent's name in DM Sans 600 16px and the note body in Inter 400 14px, creating a visual 'quoted speech' pattern that echoes human conversation. Pre-populated property details (rent, deposit, amenities) appear as a compact summary card with a subtle --shadow-purple-sm (0 2px 4px rgba(49,19,93,0.2)) to lift them above the background, signaling that this data was captured, not entered -- it 'arrived' on the platform from the conversation. The guest profile thumbnail uses a circular avatar (--avatar-md, 48px, --rounded-full) with a purple verification ring (2px solid --secondary-purple) to visually confirm vetting status. The single CTA at the bottom ('Review Ariel's Proposal') uses the --gradient-purple-button for the most visually assertive element on the screen. The overall visual principle: the handoff screen looks personal and curated (warm background, quoted speech pattern, pre-populated data), not systematic and generic (white background, empty form fields, multi-step wizard).

evidence.quote: If I can grab your email, I can basically get the account set up and then a lot of that information can just be sent to you right through there.
evidence.insight: Bryant promises the platform will have 'that information' -- everything they discussed. The visual treatment must signal pre-population and readiness, not blankness. Data that appears already filled in visually communicates 'we were listening,' while empty fields communicate 'start over.'

evidence.quote: Stewart personally handled the lion's share of 10,000 tweets per month and 8,000 customer support tickets.
evidence.insight: Butterfield's personal touch was the Cold Start trust mechanism. The handoff screen is where Bryant's personal touch transfers to the platform's visual language. The purple accent bar quoting the agent's note is the visual hinge point of this transfer.

evidence.quote: I've never heard of this company, I guess you... I'm on your website... I guess you're doing experience similar to Furnished Finder.
evidence.insight: Mahesh has already visited the website and is comparing to a competitor. The handoff screen must visually differentiate from both the generic website and from Furnished Finder's standard listing interface. The warm off-white, purple accents, and personalized layout are the differentiators.

colors: --secondary-purple (rgb(109,49,194)) for agent note accent bar and avatar verification ring
typography: Inter 500 13px (--text-sm-md) for pre-populated property summary labels
spacing: --spacing-md (12px) between label and value in property summary

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-off-white (rgb(252,250,255)) yields approximately 15:1, exceeding AAA. --secondary-purple (rgb(109,49,194)) on --bg-off-white yields approximately 4.8:1, passing AA for normal text. The --gradient-purple-button with white text passes AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye sees the welcome headline with host name first (largest type, top position), then the agent's quoted note (purple accent bar draws attention), then the pre-populated property card (elevated shadow), then the guest profile with verification ring (circular element attracts gaze), and finally the CTA button at the bottom (gradient purple, highest saturation). The scan path mirrors the conversation flow: greeting > what we discussed > who your guest is > what to do next.
elements.brand_alignment: Directly serves 'Relentless Personalization' from the taste model -- the host's name, their property data, and their agent's voice appear on the first screen. Serves 'Warm, not cold' through the off-white background and conversational layout. Serves 'Premium-accessible' through the shadow elevation and purple accents without excessive decoration.

elements.title: Ghost Roommate Progressive Disclosure Visual Layers
elements.problem: The ghost roommate concept triggers a dual response in Mahesh: economic interest ('I'm still getting paid whatever first month' at 10:45) and operational anxiety ('comes with little complications' at 08:31). L2 defines a three-layer progressive disclosure model (concept > preview > operations). The visual challenge is ensuring each layer looks visually distinct so the host never confuses which disclosure layer they are in, while maintaining visual continuity across the layers. If Layer 1 (evaluation teaser) and Layer 2 (full preview) look the same, the host cannot gauge how much more information is coming, increasing cognitive load. Cold Start Theory's 'context collapse' warning applies visually: two guests sharing one property could visually collapse into a confusing mosaic of overlapping schedules, names, and statuses unless the visual system clearly separates the two guest contexts.
elements.solution: Assign each disclosure layer a progressively richer visual treatment that signals increasing information density. Layer 1 (Evaluation Teaser): A single-line inline callout within the pricing section, styled as a subtle highlight band with --bg-off-white background and a thin 1px --border-color bottom border. Text in Inter 400 14px --text-gray (#6b7280): 'Weekend ghost roommate could increase total income to ~$X/mo.' No card, no elevation, no purple -- this is informational whisper, not a decision prompt. Layer 2 (Match Found Preview): A distinct card component with --shadow-md elevation, --bg-white background, and a left-border in --accent-purple (4px) to signal 'new actionable item.' Inside, the two guests are shown in a split layout: left column for the weekday guest (existing), right column for the proposed weekend guest (new). The weekend guest column has a subtle --protocol-surface (#F7F2FA) background tint to visually distinguish it as 'proposed, not confirmed.' Schedule visualization uses a simple 7-column week strip where Mon-Fri cells are filled in --secondary-purple and Sat-Sun cells in --accent-purple, creating an immediate visual mapping of who occupies which days. Layer 3 (Active Lease Operations): Full dashboard integration within the Stays Manager. The two-guest context uses a tab or toggle pattern at the top of the stay view: 'Weekday Guest | Weekend Guest' in Inter 500 14px, with the active tab underlined in --secondary-purple (2px). Each tab loads its own context (schedule, cleaning status, payment). The visual principle: the ghost roommate is introduced as a whisper (Layer 1), elevated to a card (Layer 2), and finally integrated into the dashboard architecture (Layer 3). Each visual step signals a proportional increase in commitment and complexity.

evidence.quote: I've never dealt with that kind of a situation, obviously it comes with little complications.
evidence.insight: Mahesh's anxiety triggers at the word 'complications.' The Layer 1 visual must be visually minimal (no card, no elevation) to avoid amplifying anxiety at the evaluation stage. The ghost roommate should visually feel like an optional footnote, not a featured component, until the host is ready.

evidence.quote: A ghost roommate match. So in Ariel's case, she'll be in the space Monday to Friday. And there's potential that we can find someone who'd be interested in a Friday to Monday stay.
evidence.insight: Bryant introduces the concept with a temporal split (Monday-Friday vs. Friday-Monday). The 7-column week strip visualization in Layer 2 directly maps this verbal explanation into a visual pattern the host can immediately parse.

evidence.quote: There's fraudsters, overcrowding, and context collapse -- all natural outcomes of a network that grows and matures.
evidence.insight: Two guests in one property is a miniature context collapse. The tab/toggle pattern in Layer 3 prevents this by ensuring only one guest's context is visible at a time, reducing visual noise and preventing the host from trying to process two schedules simultaneously.

colors: --secondary-purple for weekday schedule cells and active tab underline
--accent-purple for weekend schedule cells and Layer 2 left-border accent
typography: Inter 600 16px --text-dark for Layer 2 card headline ('Ghost Roommate Preview')
DM Sans 600 14px for income comparison figures in Layer 2
spacing: --spacing-2xl (24px) section separation in Layer 3 dashboard view

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Layer 1: --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-off-white (rgb(252,250,255)) yields approximately 4.7:1, passing AA for normal text. Layer 2: --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-white (#FFFFFF) yields 17:1, exceeding AAA. Schedule cell colors: --secondary-purple on white yields 4.5:1 for the filled cells, acceptable as they carry supplementary meaning (the day labels carry the primary information). Layer 3: tab text in --text-dark on --bg-white exceeds AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Layer 1: the ghost roommate callout is visually subordinate to the pricing headline and guarantee bar above it -- it is the third thing the eye hits, after guarantee and rate. Layer 2: the ghost roommate card is the primary focus of its own screen, with the split layout and week strip as the visual center. Layer 3: the tab/toggle is the top navigation element, controlling which guest context occupies the primary view area below.
elements.brand_alignment: Serves 'Confident, not flashy' by introducing a complex feature through visual restraint (whisper > card > dashboard, not a splashy feature announcement). Serves 'Trustworthy, not corporate' through the honest visual progression -- the host can see that complexity increases gradually, and is never surprised by hidden information. Serves 'Relentless Personalization' by showing the actual schedule split (Mon-Fri / Fri-Mon) specific to this booking.

elements.title: Gatekeeper Export Document Visual Authority
elements.problem: Mahesh's management company requires a guest application (04:25-04:30), and L1/L2 both identify the need for a 'Share with Management' export. The visual challenge is unique: this is a document that leaves the platform and lands in a management company's inbox, where it will be compared to standard rental applications from other sources. If the export looks like a screenshot of the Split Lease UI (purple buttons, platform-specific badges, informal language), the management company may not recognize it as a legitimate application document. Conversely, if it looks like a plain text PDF with no brand identity, the host cannot differentiate it from documents they could have compiled manually. Cold Start Theory's enterprise adoption parallel applies: 'a viral growth strategy is difficult, because it's not enough to dribble in a few users at a time.' The management company must be 'sold' visually, and the document is the sales artifact.
elements.solution: Design the Management Company Package as a PDF/printable document with a visual treatment that balances professional formality with subtle brand identification. The document uses a white (#FFFFFF) background with a single-color header band in --primary-purple (#31135D) containing the Split Lease logo in white and the document title ('Guest Application Summary') in Inter 700 18px white. Below the header, the document body uses a structured, form-like layout with clearly labeled fields: Applicant Name, Profession, Credit Check Summary (Pass/Fail with score range), Employment Verification, Intended Occupancy (dates and pattern), Monthly Rate and Deposit, and Split Lease Guarantee Terms (positioned as a co-signer/guarantor statement). Each field uses a label in Inter 600 11px --text-gray with a horizontal rule below, and a value in Inter 400 14px --text-dark -- mimicking the visual pattern of traditional rental applications. The guarantee terms section has a subtle --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6) background fill to visually elevate it, with a small Split Lease shield icon and the text 'Split Lease guarantees payment and provides $1M property protection.' At the bottom, the agent's direct contact (name, phone, email) appears in a footer. The visual principle: the document looks like what management companies expect (structured, formal, field-based) while carrying just enough brand identity (purple header, logo, guarantee section) to establish platform credibility without platform dependency (no login required, no interactive elements).

evidence.quote: I probably need that information to share with my management because they do require application.
evidence.insight: The management company expects an 'application' -- a document format with specific fields. The visual design must conform to this expectation while subtly differentiating Split Lease from a standard self-submitted application.

evidence.quote: Do I have to send most of them to, to find management company I'm here on something that I'll have to, I'll have to figure out?
evidence.insight: Mahesh is uncertain about how information flows to his management company. The document must look complete and self-contained so the host does not need to assemble or explain it -- it is the entire communication, not a supplement.

evidence.quote: There are enterprise products like Workday that require the company to implement them before there's any value. Here, a viral growth strategy is difficult.
evidence.insight: The management company is a micro-enterprise gate. The document is the platform's enterprise sales artifact -- it must visually communicate legitimacy and completeness to a third party that has no prior relationship with Split Lease.

colors: --white (#FFFFFF) for header text and logo, and for document body background
typography: Inter 700 18px for document title in header
spacing: --spacing-sm (8px) between label and value within each field
new_tokens_needed: --export-header-height: 64px (fixed header band height for print consistency)
--export-field-rule: 1px solid #e5e7eb (horizontal rule between label and value)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AAA for the document body (it may be printed or viewed on low-quality screens). --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-white (#FFFFFF) yields 17:1. --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-white yields 5.7:1, passing AA for normal text and AAA for large text. White text on --primary-purple (#31135D) yields 13.5:1, exceeding AAA. The document must remain legible when printed in grayscale -- the purple header becomes a dark gray bar, maintaining hierarchy.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye sees the purple header band with logo and title first (brand identification), then scans down the structured fields in reading order (applicant > financial > occupancy > guarantee), and rests on the guarantee terms section (visually distinguished by the light-gray background fill). The agent contact footer anchors the bottom. The scan mimics how a management company employee processes a standard application.
elements.brand_alignment: Serves 'Trustworthy, not corporate' by using a clean, structured format that conveys institutional legitimacy without the impersonal density of a legal document. Serves 'Premium-accessible' through the single brand-color header that elevates the document above a plain-text PDF without overdesigning it. The restraint (one color, one font family, structured fields) aligns with 'Confident, not flashy.'

elements.title: Cumulative Lease Health Visual Meter
elements.problem: Ariel's 3-month lease is a stability test (L0: 'start with three months and then ideally extend if it was something that worked for her' at 03:26). L1 defines a 'Three-Month Atomic Network Stability Threshold' and L2 defines a 'Cumulative Evidence Dashboard.' The visual challenge: how do you make cumulative progress feel tangible and advancing, rather than static? Standard dashboard metrics (total income, payment count) are numerical and abstract. They answer 'what happened' but not 'how am I doing' or 'am I on track?' Cold Start Theory's Slack threshold ('after 2,000 messages, 93% of those customers are still using Slack today') is powerful because it is a milestone, not a metric. The visual system must transform 12-13 weeks of transactional data into a progress narrative that the host can feel advancing toward a positive outcome -- the renewal decision.
elements.solution: Design a 'Lease Health' visual meter as the primary element on the active lease dashboard. The meter is a horizontal progress bar spanning the full content width, divided into 12-13 segments (one per weekly stay). Completed weeks fill in --secondary-purple (rgb(109,49,194)) from left to right. The current week pulses with a subtle animation (opacity oscillation between 0.6 and 1.0 at --animation-duration 1.5s) in --accent-purple. Future weeks remain in --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6). Milestone markers at weeks 4, 8, and 12 are visually emphasized with small diamond indicators above the bar in --primary-purple with labels ('Month 1', 'Month 2', 'Month 3'). Below the progress bar, three aggregate KPIs appear in a horizontal row of compact cards: (1) Total Income Received (DM Sans 700 24px --primary-purple, the largest number on the screen), (2) On-Time Payment Rate (Inter 600 16px --text-dark, as a percentage), (3) Incidents (Inter 600 16px --text-dark, ideally '0' rendered in --secondary-purple to make zero feel positive). At the 3-month mark, the meter fills completely with a completion animation (left-to-right fill in 0.6s ease-out) and a 'Lease Performance Summary' overlay card appears with the renewal CTA. The visual principle: the host should be able to glance at the dashboard and immediately see 'I am X weeks into a 12-week journey, everything is green, here is how much I have earned.' The progress bar converts abstract time into visible advancement.

evidence.quote: Start with three months and then ideally extend if it was something that worked for her.
evidence.insight: The 3-month period is an explicit evaluation window. The progress bar makes this window visible and bounded, converting an open-ended question ('Is this working?') into a visual journey with a clear destination.

evidence.quote: After 2,000 messages, 93% of those customers are still using Slack today.
evidence.insight: Slack's threshold was powerful because it was measurable and cumulative. The weekly progress bar is Split Lease's visual equivalent: each filled segment is evidence accumulating toward the retention threshold. The host can see they are past the point of no return.

evidence.quote: I've never heard of this company... I guess you're doing experience similar to Furnished Finder.
evidence.insight: Zero prior relationship means the 3-month lease is the entire trust-building window. The visual meter must make every successful week feel like a step forward, counteracting the anti-network-effect impulse to revert to a known competitor.

colors: --primary-purple (#31135D) for milestone diamond markers and total income number
typography: DM Sans 700 24px for total income KPI (largest number on dashboard)
Inter 600 16px for secondary KPIs (payment rate, incident count)
Inter 400 12px for KPI sublabels ('Total Received', 'On-Time Rate', 'Incidents')
spacing: --spacing-lg (16px) vertical space between progress bar and KPI row
--spacing-2xl (24px) top/bottom margin for the entire meter component

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. --secondary-purple (rgb(109,49,194)) filled segments on --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6) background yields approximately 4.3:1 -- acceptable as the bar is a decorative/progress element, not text. The milestone labels in --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-white (#FFFFFF) yield 5.7:1, passing AA. The total income number in --primary-purple (#31135D) on --bg-white yields 13.5:1, exceeding AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye sees the progress bar first (full-width, colored, unique shape on the page), then drops to the total income KPI (largest typography), then scans right to the secondary KPIs (payment rate, incidents). Milestone labels are peripheral -- they orient but do not demand attention. The renewal CTA at month 3 becomes the visual focus only when the bar is complete.
elements.brand_alignment: Serves 'Relentless Personalization' by showing the host's specific journey progress, not generic data. Serves 'Warm, not cold' through the purple-filled gradient rather than a cold green/red status system. Serves taste model animation philosophy ('fast response, gentle settle') via the current-week pulse and the completion animation. The 'One signature animation per component' principle is honored: the only animation is the current-week pulse.

elements.title: Counterparty Clarity Visual Map
elements.problem: Mahesh cannot parse the contractual structure from conversation alone (11:27: 'The agreement is, is it between which we, you know, for me, at least on my side, is it with you guys or it's a, the record?'). L2 defines an 'Agreement Counterparty Clarity Architecture' with a responsibility map. The visual challenge is representing a three-party relationship (host, guest, platform) in a way that is immediately parseable without reading dense text. Traditional legal documents list parties in paragraphs; digital products often use a single 'terms' link. Neither works for a host who needs to know, at a glance, who handles payments, who handles damage, and who they communicate with. Cold Start Theory's atomic network requires 'the right people, at the same time, using the product in the right way' -- visually, each participant's role must be as clear as a labeled node in a network diagram.
elements.solution: Design an 'Arrangement Summary' card that uses a minimal three-column visual layout: Host (you) | Split Lease | Guest. Each column is headed by a role label in Inter 600 12px --text-gray, with the participant's name below in Inter 500 14px --text-dark. Below the column headers, a series of horizontal rows map each responsibility to its handler using a simple filled-dot indicator: Payments row shows the dot in the Split Lease column (--secondary-purple, 10px circle), Property Protection shows the dot in the Split Lease column, Communication shows dots in both the Host and Guest columns (indicating direct communication), and Disputes shows the dot in the Split Lease column. Row labels use Inter 400 13px --text-description (#374151). The entire card uses --bg-white with --shadow-sm elevation and --rounded-lg (8px) corners. The Split Lease column has a subtle --protocol-surface (#F7F2FA) background tint to visually distinguish the platform as the intermediary party. This card appears as a persistent sidebar element on the lease dashboard and is promoted to primary position on agreement-signing and claim-initiation screens. The visual principle: the host should never need to read a paragraph to understand who handles what. The dot-matrix layout converts legal complexity into spatial clarity in under 5 seconds.

evidence.quote: The agreement is, is it between which we, you know, for me, at least on my side, is it with you guys or it's a, the record?
evidence.insight: Mahesh's confusion is audible in his fragmented phrasing. He cannot construct the mental model verbally. The visual map does the construction for him: three columns, clear dots, no ambiguity.

evidence.quote: How does the deposit get sorted out? Is that something that I would work with you or would that with the...
evidence.insight: For each responsibility type, Mahesh asks 'is it you or them?' The dot-matrix answers all such questions simultaneously: scan the row, see the dot, know the counterparty.

evidence.quote: Solving the Cold Start Problem requires getting all the right users and content on the same network at the same time.
evidence.insight: The atomic network has clear participant roles. The visual map makes these roles structurally visible, converting an abstract network into a concrete arrangement the host can reference at any time.

typography: Inter 600 12px uppercase for column headers ('Host', 'Split Lease', 'Guest')
spacing: --spacing-xs (4px) between column header and participant name

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-white (#FFFFFF) yields 5.7:1, passing AA. --text-description (#374151) on --bg-white yields 9.7:1, exceeding AAA. --secondary-purple dots (rgb(109,49,194)) on both --bg-white and --protocol-surface (#F7F2FA) yield 4.5:1+, passing AA for graphic elements. All text on the platform-tinted column: --text-dark on #F7F2FA yields approximately 15:1.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye sees the three-column structure first (spatial layout communicates 'relationship map'). Then the purple dots draw attention to where responsibilities are assigned (they are the only saturated elements in the card). Then the row labels identify what each responsibility is. The column headers (Host, Split Lease, Guest) anchor the spatial meaning. The card is small enough to be glanceable but detailed enough to answer 'who handles what?' without expansion.
elements.brand_alignment: Serves 'Trustworthy, not corporate' by replacing legal jargon with a spatial diagram. Serves 'Confident, not flashy' through the minimal dot-matrix pattern with no icons, illustrations, or decorative elements. Serves 'Premium-accessible' through the elevated card with subtle shadow and the purple-tinted platform column that signals Split Lease's intermediary role without overstating it.
